intro: Cheiranthus argillosus, commonly known as the claycress, is a flowering plant native to Europe, Asia, and North Africa. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes many other economically important plants such as cabbages and mustards. The plant typically grows in disturbed soils and is characterized by its small, yellow or white flowers and pinnately divided leaves. It has a short life cycle and is often found in rocky or clay-rich habitats. Cheiranthus argillosus is also known for its ability to thrive in poor soil conditions, making it a hardy and resilient species.
